context.speaker: Mark Wilmer
context.text: Your Honor, under the Compact, the Upper Basin assumed that they obligation in 3 (c) -- in 3 (d), assume the obligation knowingly, willingly, purposely that they would deliver on an average 7,500,000 every year at Lee Ferry.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: So if -- if in discharging that obligation that leads them with less than that in the Upper Basin, they accept the deficiency?

context.speaker: Mark Wilmer
context.text: That is a calculated risk they took to get the consent --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, I didn't quite understand your answer to Mr. Justice Black.

context.speaker: Mark Wilmer
context.text: I'm sorry Your Honor, I meant to say this that nothing that Your Honors do today or I shouldn't say today I mean in the decision of this case.

context.speaker: Mark Wilmer
context.text: Nothing Your Honors can do in the decision of -- should do in the decision of this case assuming that it is a statutory construction case with respect to the meeting of what with respect to what Congress meant in enacting the Project Act can effect the Upper Basin.

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: Not -- what can we do if we abandon that aqueduct to the sun, how can we do something else about it?

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: Nobody's offered to pay for the alternative source that would take our water to give it to the Central Arizona project.

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: It's outside the scope of this case if I may respectfully say so.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Now, may I ask you, Mr. Ely, how would you reply to Justice Douglas, assuming the Master's Report (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: Well, I first want to --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I thought (Inaudible) --

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: And so again, we would have the clear conflict between claims based on events that have already occurred.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: Now, on the other table, I will show you the difference in the allocation of the mainstream under the Master's Report and California's proposal.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: And there again, there is an obvious conflict between the rights that California says she has today based on past events and the rights which Arizona and Nevada say they have today, based on past contracts with the Secretary.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: General, Justice Stewart appears to mean if you have the history of problems, when you have California (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: Yes, yes.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: It is based on -- this is an allocation of the mainstream but the computation is based on a universe that would include the Gila.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: The policy in this matter changes from time to time and the number of Indians may grow from time to time.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: Furthermore, I suggest that the fact that an Indian moves off the reservation or just as somebody moves off reclaimed land should not indicate that he or his tribe has been deprived of the use of that land just because he doesn't live on it.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: He and his tribe, without attempting now to divide between them or to be too precisely, would seem to be entitled to the practical use to them in form of income or state, or call it what you will, of that land that has been set apart for them.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: May I ask you if that is in somewhat the same philosophy that Mr. Justice Douglas have suggested in Washington?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: In other words, if they get -- when the reservation was created, it implied that they should have enough water to irrigate the land?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: The land stayed with them is there.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: If the Court please, we -- we request that it be retained as it is written in the final decree.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: I hope not.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Inaudible) Mr. Justice Black (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: Certainly, sir, thank you.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: May it please the Court.

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: Can 3,100,000 acre-feet be claimed in its entirety from the stretch of the river from Lake Mead to Mexico, the area in red on the maps before you, or may it be claimed instead from the area in red plus the tributaries shown in blue?

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: We say the latter.

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: If we we're right, then some-two million acre-feet of that 3,100,000 is accounted for by those tributary uses not over 1,100,000 maybe acclaimed within Article III (a) from the main river, the red area, by Arizona and Nevada.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Does Justice Black's question become circling in cases where there was planning in tributaries in the Lower Basin?

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: No sir.

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: It --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But, after we've had the figures of the exposition in your part, is it true that all this is irrelevant to the problem we have to face on your -- on the basis of your argument that, in any event -- in any event, what goes through -- what gets to the Lower Basin is unaffected by what the Upper Basin may get out of its hypothetical or out of this abstract seven million fund?

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: Well, my -- the thrust of my argument is simply to answer the Master's reassurance to us, there's no possibility of shortage, the Compact is irrelevant.

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: You're concerned what Congress does here after, I don't know, it may never build this project.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What I was -- in answer to Justice Black's question is we needn't bother about these figures, whatever may be the differences, the fact is that 7,500,000 is merely an unreal ceiling for the Upper Basin.

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: That is right.

context.speaker: Northcutt Ely
context.text: We're -- we are trying to meet his hypothesis that there is no possibility of shortage of 7.5 million from the red area, the mainstream, from Lee Fer -- from Lake Mead to Mexico.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I see.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: May I ask this question?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I uphold Justice Black's question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The answer that you give, we can forget all about the Upper Basin, there's no bearing to the -- on the controversy.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That's true, isn't it?

A. L. Mechling Barge Lines, Inc. v. Unit.speaker: Justice Black

A. L. Mechling Barge Lines, Inc. v. Unit.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 09, 1961

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Do you -- did they ask for it?

context.speaker: Daniel M. Friedman
context.text: Well, I think by implication they have in view of the settled, established practice.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I don't know if it is crucial in the case but I -- and when you ask for temporary injunction, ordinarily, the statute which requires that there's a limitation at the time that temporary injunction can be granted and even in states where they provide that temporary injunction can be granted as a rule as I recall it for a limited time.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: But they asked for it and as Justice Whittaker, indicated they give some kind of showing as to why they should have it.

context.speaker: Daniel M. Friedman
context.text: Well --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: And it's only in the rarest instances as I recall that they grant it for over a period of a certain number of days without giving the other side a right to be heard.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Just a --

context.speaker: Gilbert A. Cornfield
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I'm sorry to back track a little bit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Before you get into the Norris-LaGuardia, I'm going little further with Justice Douglas' inquiry, a little different aspect of it with respect to the individual employees when you say for several reasons cannot be made defendants here, could an individual employee covered by collective bargaining agreement which contained a no lockout clause sue as an individual, sue the employer -- employer under Section 301 if he were locked out?

context.speaker: Gilbert A. Cornfield
context.text: I would say this Your Honor that the commitment regarding the lockout runs to the union.

context.speaker: Gilbert A. Cornfield
context.text: And this is my own view of the matter that the proper party would be the union to sue.

context.speaker: Charles S. Burdell
context.text: That is not true, of course, of the smaller newspapers in the other counties.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: You didn't mention Klickitat County where television reception is practically nonexistent.

context.speaker: Charles S. Burdell
context.text: No, I didn't mention that because everyone goes fishing there so they don't have to watch television Mr. Justice, in Klickitat County.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: Mr. Burdell, aside from the county mentioned by my Brother Justice Douglas, is there any other county where there isn't fair reception of television in your state?

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: These two counties that you mentioned in your affidavit, is there a coverage, television coverage, in those counties?

context.speaker: Charles S. Burdell
context.text: There is some -- oh, yes there is some television coverage.

context.speaker: Charles S. Burdell
context.text: That's the way it is right now, although the Constitution of the State of Washington of course provides it in criminal cases we have a right to an appeal.

context.speaker: Charles S. Burdell
context.text: But they have not affirmed or reversed it just as the judgment of the trial court stands.

context.speaker: Charles S. Burdell
context.text: And there I am.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Now, suppose the law of your state, suppose the law of Washington required you, intellectually required you to that of Justice Harlan's question by saying that the law of Washington so far as it is officially declared than that of the legislature of Washington which said the grand jury need not be a fair-minded disinterested body hearing, would you be – would your case, would you be in a different situation if you had to make that answer?

context.speaker: Charles S. Burdell
context.text: Oh yes, I think, I would.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You mean, you'd be bound that we will then -- that this trial would've been alright from your point of view with reference to the federal constitution?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But the fact that it does go to your complete answer because as I understand you said this is a complete answer to say that the petty jury was fairly selected.

context.speaker: James E. Kennedy
context.text: Yes, in this case.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And if that's no more of a complete answer in one case than in the other so far as I can see.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Justice Jackson would -- I must -- I'm bothered to say with a great deal of course thought that all -- all those cases were wrong.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I don't understand that argument getting with me or not in the brief.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But if you start with those cases, I do not see the answer that you've just made in a situation in which -- starting with an assumption that the grand jury was biased in the -- selected so that there couldn't be a fair judgment by it which to me may well be fall under due process.

context.speaker: James E. Kennedy
context.text: Yes, I think that's the distinction between the exercise of this Court's --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, I understand if it is supervisory jurisdiction but --

context.speaker: James E. Kennedy
context.text: Then it's a matter for the appropriate appellate court and it's not a federal constitutional question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, I put it to you in what Justice Jackson out, I have great difficulty in seeing the difference between a constitutionally required protection such as the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendment and the generality of the Due Process Clause.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I can see that you may not bring yourself within it and that's what you're going to show us.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: In fact, still bring even on the assumption that it is relevant, that which you're going to deal with, aren't you?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And said, “We'll avoid all these legal controversies, all the business that we just filed an information that cuts the ground from under.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You could've done that.

context.speaker: James E. Kennedy
context.text: Yes, we could've.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But your argument is -- because you could've done it, and didn't, that shows that on the starting point of Mr. Justice Harlan made, the point is no good.

context.speaker: James E. Kennedy
context.text: Yes, it's -- I say it's no good for this reason, the complaint here, the petitioner's complaint in essence that he did not have an impartial accuser.

context.speaker: James E. Kennedy
context.text: Well, I filed quite a few cases, I don't think I've ever been impartial.

context.speaker: James E. Kennedy
context.text: I have -- I prejudged it, I think the man is guilty, I wouldn't file it and I am biased and I don't think that that violates anybody's constitutional right and that's what petitioner in essence is complaining about here.

context.speaker: James E. Kennedy
context.text: He did not have an impartial accuser.

context.speaker: James E. Kennedy
context.text: Now, in the race cases that Your Honor refers to, the -- that I think it -- those are best analyzed by Mr. Justice Jackson's dissent where he points out as a disciplinary proceeding and it's the only practicable way in fact of enforcing these rights that these certain states cannot discriminate against these people or they're going to have to go do it all over again because its --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Kennedy, I -- as my concurring opinion in that case showed, I had sympathy with his argument as a matter of principle as we say, that the laws in dating that (Inaudible) had -- the decision of this Court had been otherwise and no use of -- dealing with this problem by saying that Justice Jackson's dissent is persuasive.

context.speaker: James E. Kennedy
context.text: I say it -- I think they correctly analyzed the basis for the decision and why it is -- I believe this Court will adhere to those because it is -- as much as anything --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The fact of the matter is in those cases, the fact of the matter is that an otherwise invulnerable to trial and conviction is nullified because the grand jury was found to had a vice, isn't that right?

Benz v. New York State Thruway Authority.speaker: Justice Stewart
Benz v. New York State Thruway Authority.case_name: Benz v. New York State Thruway Authority
Benz v. New York State Thruway Authority.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 28, 1962

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, are saying this to the face of that agreement, you can't get $70,000 unless somehow that agreement is reformed, is that it?

context.speaker: Lauren D. Rachlin
context.text: Yes sir, yes sir.

context.speaker: Lauren D. Rachlin
context.text: I can't get the just compensation to which we are entitled.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: As Mr. Justice Frankfurter suggest, couldn't you cash your complaint in the Court of Claims in the form of a demand for $70,000 for the property that was taken?

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And that the state would defend and say, “Aha!

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: No, you've made an agreement to sell it for $3500.”

context.speaker: Allan F. Conwill
context.text: I might say that we can do apply a test in 16 (b) cases similar to a test applied by a distinguished jury as happened in the Sixth Circuit in Fredo against Newman, that is, you look at the transaction and the relationship and determine from that whether or not there is a danger of the use of inside information.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Now, is that particular case has got quite a different issue.

context.speaker: Allan F. Conwill
context.text: It's quite a different issue, I agree, but the basic reasoning to us is relevant.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, it can't -- they can't be quite as loose that you've just put it because the danger in the hypothesis given by Justice Stewart, if it's merely a question of danger, then you could be with the brother and the wife situation.

context.speaker: Allan F. Conwill
context.text: I agree--

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If you look at the specific -- if that's the test.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, I don't want to make a fine point of it, but you have to say it is a part -- that it is a director, not equal to, but a director.

context.speaker: Allan F. Conwill
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Allan F. Conwill
context.text: We're not saying really “equal to,” we're saying that, for purposes of Section 16 (b), we're urging the Court to consider Lehman Brothers as a director.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: May I ask you please, did I correctly understand you to say, in answer to Mr. Justice Frankfurter, that you consider it vital to your case that we consider director to include partnership as the form of word is used in 16 (b)?

context.speaker: Allan F. Conwill
context.text: Well, that is the legal rationale by which we arrive at the result which we urge, Mr. Justice Whittaker.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: Well, suppose that a partner actually, beneficially interested, had such equity securities taking the names of other people.
If the Court ought to try to remedy an evil here by extending the statute, why not wives and brothers and uncles and everybody else?
They're all the people that Congress excluded, and I submit that there's no stopping.
And, here, Congress passed a penal statute with a conclusive presumption, selected those who were to be liable, and I submit, there's no basis for extending it beyond that.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: How do you deal with Justice Jackson's opinion in the -- was it the Mosser case?
Well, I don't know that I'm prepared to deal with the result.
I don't -- it hasn't been --
I beg your pardon, page 24.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Just as a matter of curiosity, Mr. Seymour.
Yes, sir?

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Your answer to Mr. Justice Frankfurter -- I might have to assume that law firms these days are taking short-swing profits?
No, I don't.
I don't.
-- that that isn't so.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Well, a partner -- law partners, I assume, keep the $50-fee for directors and they keep it themselves, so the --
Mr. Justice, you're a survivor of a day which is a happier day.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Seymour, that was (Inaudible) element in view of Justice Black's interventions, I hope I did not imply that I regard that as the most desirable aspects of their legal profession.
No, I --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I didn't mean to make any such implications.

Brown Shoe Company, Inc. v. United State.case_name: Brown Shoe Company, Inc. v. United States

context.speaker: Arthur H. Dean
context.text: In conclusion, may it please the Court, we submit that there was complete failure to analyze the evidence on the part of the District Court.

context.speaker: Arthur H. Dean
context.text: The Government has accepted the fact that there was no substantial lessening of competition in manufacturing.

context.speaker: Arthur H. Dean
context.text: And we believe that our briefs and the evidence will conclusively show that there was no substantial lessening of competition in the retail field or in the manufacturing and retail field combined.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Dean, on your opening argument, Mr. Justice Harlan asked you the question as to jurisdiction namely, whether -- whether you thought this case was properly here under -- under 25 U.S.C Section 29, and I wondered if you and the Solicitor General would be willing to submit a memorandum to us on that score.

context.speaker: Arthur H. Dean
context.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Would you that please?

Brown Shoe Company, Inc. v. United State.speaker: Justice Warren
Brown Shoe Company, Inc. v. United State.case_name: Brown Shoe Company, Inc. v. United States
Brown Shoe Company, Inc. v. United State.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 06, 1961 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Arthur H. Dean
context.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Would you that please?

context.speaker: Arthur H. Dean
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: So that there won't be any misunderstanding, I'm going to ask Mr. Justice Harlan, if you will restate the question because he'd like it to have it.

context.speaker: John M. Harlan II
context.text: Well, I wonder if I could restate it because the Solicitor General's answer doesn't satisfy me, that is the answer.

context.speaker: John M. Harlan II
context.text: My problem is this, whether or not in view of the fact of this decree, although in paragraph 1, undertook to order an unqualified divestiture, nevertheless, goes on to say in paragraph 4 that the divestiture is to be subject to approval of the court on notice by parties in submission of the plan, whether an appeal at this stage satisfies the particular requirements of 15 U.S.C. in Section 29.

context.text: Absolutely and I'm also taking up the statements that were made in the Anastaplo to exactly the same effect where this young man as an attorney for example, stated that he would not subscribe to the proposition that he did not believe in the overthrow of the Government by force or violence under certain circumstances that might exist at some long time in the future, but it was quite clear that he believed that these circumstances were not present within our society or our civilization at the present time.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Simon, we'll reduce it to very simple terms.

Cramp v. Board of Public Instruction or.speaker: Justice Warren
Cramp v. Board of Public Instruction or.case_name: Cramp v. Board of Public Instruction or Orange County
Cramp v. Board of Public Instruction or.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 16, 1961

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: All I'm suggesting is that it doesn't prevent anybody from expressing the most vehement disagreement with any specific provision of the Constitution and yet to require him to say that he wants the change made by the way in which the Constitution has indicated changes should be made.

context.speaker: Tobias Simon
context.text: Well --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Simon, but -- also, I think there are some states in -- I'm trying to think my own, I ought to know because I took the oath a good many times, but I think there are a good many of them that require a man to -- to take an oath that he will not only support the Constitution, but the laws of the State of California.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Now, they don't carry, the laws don't carry that implicit thing in them for -- for repeal Mr. Justice Frankfurter has -- has been talking about.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: But I suppose that when I took the oath to support the Constitution of the State -- Constitution and laws of the State of California that I wasn't saying that I believe in the wisdom and the policy of every law that was on our statute books.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I took the oath that I would support them because they were on the statute books and there is a difference between belief in what you will -- what you will do as a public official.

context.speaker: J. R. Wells

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Where -- where his advocacy or belief or what not promotes a wholly lawful phase of a subversive organizations' activities.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: What rights of a communist can be invaded and be subject to redress without the same invasion giving a loyal American citizen a right to redress?

context.speaker: J. R. Wells
context.text: Well, a communist or a person who has lent aid or support to the Communist Party years ago and has reformed then he would be entitled to raise a question as to whether that was a bill of attainder or ex post facto law as to whether how that -- it would be answered, it would be a different question but he would be entitled to raise that question as to whether there was passed to him a bill of attainder or ex post facto law.

context.speaker: J. R. Wells
context.text: But I don't think that a person who says that he has never lent aid, support and so forth to the Communist Party can raise the question as to whether it's an ex post facto law or bill of attainder because it couldn't possibly be as to him.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Yes, but suppose a man -- a man like Justice Frankfurter was talking about, a man who had supported certain causes that the Communist Party supports.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Suppose he supported a broad program of public housing, a broad program of maternal care, broad program of let us say public medicine and things of that kind, suppose he supported those things permanently but did not support any of their subversive programs, would he then -- would he -- wouldn't he then have a -- have to stop, look and listen before he signed any such affidavit for fear, three or four half a dozen people would say I saw him on the platform with so and so.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I saw him when the communists were advocating this or advocating that.

context.speaker: Earl Warren

context.speaker: Porter R. Chandler
context.text: Pursuing the question that I had before lunch with Mr. Justice Stewart and I apologize for misnaming Mr. -- Mr. Justice Whittaker.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I wish Justice Whittaker were here.

context.speaker: Porter R. Chandler
context.text: On the Barnette case on the flag salute, I want to make quite plain that our position is that the flag salute even before the words "under God" were put into it was regarded as a religious right by the Jehovah's Witnesses and was so treated by this Court.

context.speaker: Porter R. Chandler
context.text: The Jehovah's Witnesses thought that the flag salute even without those words was the worship of graven images and exposed a participant to power of damnation and if my friends are right in their contention, any conscientious, agnostic or atheist can object to the flag salute in its present form and cannot merely ask to have it -- have his child excused but can ask to have it embo -- abolished and that is the case that's now pending in the New York Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: William J. Butler
context.text: One is a affirmation of allegiance to a country and the other is a -- act of political -- of religious faith?

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I don't know -- I don't think you've answered it because the --

context.speaker: William J. Butler
context.text: Maybe I can answer it better Mr. -- in the words of Mr. Justice Frankfurter.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: William J. Butler

context.speaker: William J. Butler

context.speaker: William J. Butler

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The fla -- the validity of the flag salute in the New York schools now before us?

context.speaker: William J. Butler

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I'd like to ask you this question, before Justice Stewart's question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I hastily tried to read the petition.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Does the petition anywhere allege that any of your five objectors, I mean your five present petitioners object to the content of this prayer?

context.speaker: William J. Butler
context.text: There's no legal significance, no legal interpretation.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well but --

context.speaker: William J. Butler
context.text: All we say is --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- is going to interrupt the whole -- not the whole, but the basic problem with reference to the reading of the Bible, the question of Justice Harlan, asked you about terms on the fact that to -- one of the important of the major religious beliefs in this country reject the King James Version, and therefore to subject children, I'm not expressing an opinion on that, I'm just stating what the view is, and therefore, to subject children to the reading of the King James Version, New English -- "The New English Testament" is subjecting them to -- to religious utterances contrary to their faith because they have a different authorized version, namely "The Catholic Bible."

context.speaker: William J. Butler
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But that is -- so that there is a diff -- there is an objection to the Bible cases to the content of what it says.

context.speaker: Bertram B. Daiker
context.text: The question revolves itself particularly around that question of compulsion.

context.text: May I ask you one question?

context.speaker: Bertram B. Daiker
context.text: Mr. Justice Black?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: When you began to discuss the -- you referred to Justice Frankfurter's reference to this prayer as an avowal of faith, I gathered then that you agreed to the (Inaudible) and I have assumed from what you are saying now that you do agree to it, is that right?

context.speaker: Bertram B. Daiker
context.text: Agreed to the words "avowal of faith"?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: That the prayer is itself is an avowal of faith.

context.speaker: J. F. Brauer, Jr.
context.text: And he's committed to one of the institutions, you see.

context.speaker: J. F. Brauer, Jr.
context.text: And all of that proceeding was based on this written statement along with the oral one.

context.speaker: J. F. Brauer, Jr.
context.text: Then about two weeks, I guess after he was so adjudged to be juvenile delinquent, the victim died and they began instituting the proceedings to try him for murder in a District Court.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: The statement to which Mr. Justice Brennan referred is the only one I was able to find throughout this evidence in which he gave a reason why he signed the paper.

context.speaker: J. F. Brauer, Jr.
context.text: It maybe, Your Honor, that that's it but it seems to me somewhere in there, he said that he signed it because he thought he was told that they would let him out of security and go home if he did sign it, that they would keep him in security if he didn't.

context.speaker: J. F. Brauer, Jr.
context.text: I believe that's in there.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Realistically means importing the tone as you call it, tone -- the tone of the record.

context.text: I think actually these records indicate that what did they do -- the mere presence of their being there, and some of the findings say that they were Negroes sitting at a white lunch counter.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, under Justice Harlan's analysis, you could -- you could pose the question in Thompson against Louisville in that same way.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You could say in that case, it was said it's necessary to read the statute as though the City of Louisville has an ordinance saying that a man with at least record sitting in a restaurant, waiting for a bus and shuffling his feet was guilty of disorderly conduct.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The question there whether it was -- such a statute was -- whether such a statute violated the Fourteenth Amendment --

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But you do accept the tender of the legal question which Justice Black's question proffered?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You do -- do you accept that is the issue as raised by Justice Black and that you have said as I understood you, namely, may the state pass a statute intervening with are presence on, particularly in this case, I mean with the word “private premises,” premise that's not dedicated to general public use, where the owner himself had no objection to such presence or the owner himself does not indicate that he wants the person for whatever reason to leave his premises.

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.
context.text: In other words --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: You will discuss that question of fact here?

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But you do accept the tender of the legal question which Justice Black's question proffered?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You do -- do you accept that is the issue as raised by Justice Black and that you have said as I understood you, namely, may the state pass a statute intervening with are presence on, particularly in this case, I mean with the word “private premises,” premise that's not dedicated to general public use, where the owner himself had no objection to such presence or the owner himself does not indicate that he wants the person for whatever reason to leave his premises.

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.
context.text: In other words --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Do you accept it -- I've rephrased what was questioned -- admirably stated.

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.
context.text: No sir, if I understand your question, may the state adopt the law which requires segregation on private premises, no sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Pardon me?

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.
context.text: If your question is --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: No, I go back -- instead of rephrasing and we get into the lawyer's troubles, you heard Justice Black's question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Do you accept that that for you the issue in this case as he put it?

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.
context.text: If he means can the state pass a law refusing admission to private property even though the owner wants the person on there, my answer to that is no, the state cannot.

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.
context.text: No sir, we have no affirmative action of other state.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: We had such a case some years ago, with many years ago, in my time and New York required certain nondiscrimination, we haven't got that case here or have we got the question that Justice Black puts to you?

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.
context.text: We have --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: So that it does get down as he suggested to you, a discussion of the precise and concrete facts in these three cases to see whether they come within what you regard as the state couldn't do, namely, intervene where the state -- where the owner of the so-called private enterprise has not himself intervened, as I understood his question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Namely, the constitutional restriction upon your Supreme Court to review only questions of law, is that right, under the Constitution?

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You said a minute ago in answer to Justice Stewart's question that in the Sanford case, the Court found inadequacy or invalidity on the facts, did I mishear you?

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.
context.text: No sir, no sir.

context.speaker: John F. Ward, Jr.
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Robert L. Carter

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.text: Mr. Carter, on the basis of your reply to Justice Harlan, I'd like to put you this case and let me say by way of preface that I'm never troubled by questions of degree of a necessity of growing lines.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Suppose instead of this kind of an investigation, we had a totally different case that these 14 men, who were, according to the record in this case, authenticated or identified Communists, suppose you didn't have that situation, but these 14 men were named in some publication as Communists or charged with being Communists and they there -- because of that -- on that -- on the basis of that publication brought a libel suit.

context.speaker: Kirby W. Patterson
context.text: Yes, sir?

context.text: I'm a little puzzled --

context.speaker: Kirby W. Patterson

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: Kirby W. Patterson
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But it's also -- I don't quite get the consistency of that position, although I think you said to Justice Stewart namely that you can't tell from the --

context.speaker: Kirby W. Patterson

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

Glidden Company v. Zdanok.speaker: Justice Frankfurter

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: It takes -- it doesn't take care of contingencies.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If the Chief Justice confronted with an application for sua sponte there's a need to judge in some district, we naturally would pause if we don't -- if this isn't decided in sending a Court of Custom Appeal man to some other place than district, if that's all what would be decided in this case.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If he had only the direction of the Court of Appeals just as a practical matter as you suppose you thought.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But I'm suggesting that as a matter of the adjudicatory requirements of this case, do we have to travel outside as Justice Harlan asked you a little while ago outside of the scope set by the Court of Appeals?

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: Certainly, one does not have to travel beyond the scope of the fact that this involves an assignment to the District of Columbia Court but I do not concede that there's any lack of a constitutional requirement that a case here in the District of Columbia for this District of Columbia Court be heard other than by a non-Article III judge.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And as a matter -- I also appreciate why you want them invoked, why you press due process, I understand that.

Glidden Company v. Zdanok.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
Glidden Company v. Zdanok.title: ORAL ARGUMENT, PART 1: LURK V. UNITED STATES - FEBRUARY 21, 1962 (481)

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: If ever there was a proceeding which invoked and call forth and necessitated the exercise of Article III functions of this District Court, it was this trial of this petitioner for the -- a felony under the District of Columbia Code.

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: And I suggest that it is impossible from any standpoint to say that this trial of this petitioner involved anything other than the exercise of this Court's Article III judicial functions as defined in the Constitution.

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: The criminal power is the very essence of judicial power.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Does anybody sug -- why should anybody suggest that the trial over which Justice Jackson presided for as unlike or in anyway unlike in the sub -- subject matter and in the procedure was unlike the trial in the Southern District of New York or the District of Massachusetts?

context.speaker: Eugene Gressman
context.text: Well, --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That isn't in controversy, is it?

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: You say -- your statute says that even though discharged in bankruptcy, the debt must still be paid in full and one cannot have the license until it is paid in full, whereas the New York statute put a limitation of three years on it, didn't it?

context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: E. J. Skeen
context.text: And there is another limitation, the judgment debtor may pay up to $10,000 as I remember arising out of one accident and be relieved if he -- for example, there happened to be a $30,000 or $40,000 judgment against him, he could pay up to a minimum and be relieved.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What do you say to, apart from the difference that Justice Whittaker just called attention, what do you say to the consideration given by Judge Hand in writing in Reitz against Mealey for the three District Court -- for the District Court, what do you say to the considerations of Judge Hand that this business of spelling out in the statute that the creditor should ask a clerk to forward the judgment.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: It's all eyewash because that happens anyhow, that the clerk wouldn't know whether debt was paid, that he would be nudged even though the statute said nothing about it, he would be nudged by the creditor who has chief interest so far as that goes in telling the unsatisfied judgment debt forwarded to the agency and that the clerk couldn't possibly know whether the judgment debt has been discharged without -- without calling upon the judgment creditor for all this information so that spelling out in the statute, the creditor must ask the clerk, he's merely spelling out what in fact takes place in life.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What do you say to that?

context.text: Therefore, they say that there is no occasion for passing on the question of whether or not, this is to be treated like the wire and the snatch block in the other cases or whether it's to be treated like the grinding wheel in Berryhill where the Court said, “Well that was not ship's type equipment.”

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: But Mr. Colby --

context.speaker: Leavenworth Colby
context.text: What this does --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: -- my -- my question is not the same as Mr. Justice Black's.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: What I want to know is what difference does it make in this case, if the same equipment had been used whether the ship was activated or not and if the accident would have occurred in exactly the same way as it happened here?

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Why – why are you here arguing that one -- as one of your questions that this is deactivated, admittedly unseaworthy, vessel of the mothball fleet which is out of navigation and is being used for the non-maritime purpose of storing wheat, why do you make that through the first question if those are the facts?

context.speaker: Leavenworth Colby
context.text: Many times Your Honor and some of them were matters that were very wide for many doctrine about jurisdiction or anything like that Mr. --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And here's against -- here's the question was really raised on which a constitution decision have rested?

context.speaker: Leavenworth Colby
context.text: Correct.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Have you (Voice Overlap) -- have you understood for many thing I said that the implication that Mr. Justice Frankfurter made were intended to be made by me, that a man cannot defend his judgment on anything he desires.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I asked why?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: After you have been arguing a case for a long time, you took it on the position that the court had decided it that way, when the record shows it had none.

context.speaker: John B. Jones, Jr.
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Do you think it's a technical words that --

context.speaker: John B. Jones, Jr.
context.text: No, I -- we would -- it would seem to us --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, I mean what happens there where you often as much as Justice Frankfurter described what happens if law professors --

context.speaker: John B. Jones, Jr.
context.text: But there are some sessions at a judicial conference by and large those who --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: What's the agenda?

context.speaker: Kevin T. Maroney
context.text: Well, Your Honor --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: -- consistent with our rules, I think.

context.speaker: Kevin T. Maroney
context.text: Your Honor it is argued our essential position is set forth in our brief in this case at pages 38 and 39 in which we incorporate the developed argument as set forth in the Shelton brief.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: But he asked you -- Justice Black asked you if this case was cited in your brief -- in this brief and you said, “No, it was cited in the Shelton brief,” but if you rely on it this case, why isn't cited here?

context.speaker: Kevin T. Maroney
context.text: Well, we were -- we were trying to -- to make it for the convenience of the Court so that we wouldn't be unnecessarily repeating legal arguments in each brief which were common to several cases.

context.speaker: Kevin T. Maroney
context.text: And our -- we tried to -- to -- to develop a -- a master brief so called since these cases were all set together and to try to eliminate, insofar as possible, unnecessary duplicate reading as to what our position is.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: It has been held in numerous decisions by this Court, only last term on the Deutch case.This Court, we believe, made the exact distinction between elements of the crime and other issues, because in the Deutch case, the Court held as it earlier held in the Barenblatt case that a witness cannot raise at his trial for contempt the issue that he was not apprised of the pertinency of the questions, unless he questions the pertinency of the questions when he appears before the Committee.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: And on the other hand, in the Deutch case, the Court held that since the contempt of Congress statute explicitly provides that the Gov -- that the questions must be pertinent but the Government is required to prove the actual pertinency of the questions to the subject under inquiry, even though the witness makes no objection on the ground of pertinency when he appears before the Committee.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: I like to develop this contention at some length --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Before you start this, I'd like to -- of what's going with Justice Black's question from a different point of view not joining, but I ask you a question in reference to it.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Are we dealing with the immediate case before us on the assumption of the Un-American Committee investigations to present legal questions ad hoc as it grow with reference to that Committee?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Is there going to be -- is that being build up with jurisprudence specially with reference to Un-American Committee investigations or are we talking about Congressional investigations?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Are we dealing with the immediate case before us on the assumption of the Un-American Committee investigations to present legal questions ad hoc as it grow with reference to that Committee?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Is there going to be -- is that being build up with jurisprudence specially with reference to Un-American Committee investigations or are we talking about Congressional investigations?

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: I assume the latter, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That I suppose (Voice Overlap) then your answer to Justice Black's question is inadequate.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If you say in these cases, witnesses have -- 100% of them have lawyers.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That doesn't reach my concern of what the scope, the right, the power, the constitutional power, and the constitutional limitations of Congressional Investigations not Un-American Committee Investigation.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That doesn't reach my concern of what the scope, the right, the power, the constitutional power, and the constitutional limitations of Congressional Investigations not Un-American Committee Investigation.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: Your Honor, in -- in our view, it doesn't depend on the -- on the kind of Committee here and I'd say --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Alright.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Your answer isn't adequate or it doesn't meet Justice Black's question if I may say so.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: Well, I -- I suppose that ultimately we come down squarely on the whole line of cases which this -- which this Court has decided.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But not with reference to this Committee.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: Well --

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: It seems to me that perhaps with your answer to Justice -- I don't want to beset you further than you are already beset.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: That's quite alright, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Your answer to Mr. Justice Frankfurter seemed to suggest that the problem was to what extent a court will interfere with congressional committees.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: I didn't think that was in the -- these case or -- any of the cases at all, because simply --

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: No we --

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Isn't our problem that the extent of which the Federal Courts will allow themselves to become implicated in unfair proceedings before congressional committees and send people to jail who -- that the Committee wants us to put in jail or wants the District Courts with juries to put in jail.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: May I --

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Isn't it -- isn't the question of the extent of which the Federal Judiciary should become implicated in -- in these congressional investigations, it seemed -- assuming arguendo that that stepped over the bounds of fairness.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: It was -- it was the idea of Mr. Justice Frankfurter, I think expressed in his separate opinion in the Wilkinson case or some case.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: I forgot the precise name of it.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: It's been running up a common thread throughout a lot of our opinions.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Before -- may I ask a couple question with that so you can answer the fact, I'd like to know whether you think, this case has nothing to do with the scope, the right, the demand upon congressional procedures so that defiance of congressional request to answer may not be enforced to the criminal law.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Yes, there maybe two levels.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: One is where the -- the congressional inquiries beyond the scope of the Committee's authority.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: And I'm assuming that it is within the scope that Justice Harlan does that -- that it is relevant.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: The extent of which -- nevertheless courts should go or the -- should not go in lending their prestige, their imprimatur, their help to putting people in -- in prison backing up what maybe we assume arguendo is grossly unfair congressional procedures.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: Your Honors, in -- in our view, the precise question is how far the courts are going -- going to interfere if you will restrict congressional inquiries.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I'm just trying to find out whether this is like Bailey in that -- the starting point of Bailey was a series of decisions which didn't leave the question open that deemed to be open by the District Court in Mississippi.

context.speaker: Constance Baker Motley

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: Constance Baker Motley
context.text: We ask this Court to do one of two things; either refer this case back to the District Court pursuant to its power to determine the authority of the District Court and say to the District Court, “Your only authority here was to issue the injunction prayed for because the facts were conceded.

context.speaker: Constance Baker Motley
context.text: This was a public restaurant in a public airport” and the law was settled that where or is now settled by Burton that where you have a public facility which has been leased for public purpose or public use concededly then that lessee is subject to the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Constance Baker Motley
context.text: We think as this Court pointed out in Bailey yesterday, although it doesn't have jurisdiction of this appeal, it does have jurisdiction to determine the authority of the District Court.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: So, the District Court might do that, would it not?

context.text: “It is hoped that the present grand jury will not let its high office be a party to any political attempt to intimidate the Negro people in this community.”

context.speaker: Milton Kramer
context.text: Then, down at the end, “it further seems a height of hypocrisy to dust off an old blue law that has been ignored for 50 years and suddenly order its rigid enforcement against the minority group of voters.

context.speaker: Milton Kramer
context.text: However, politically popular the judge's action may be at this time, they are employing a practice far more dangerous to free elections than anything they want investigated.”

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: May I ask you to follow up Justice Brennan's question?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: What other grounds that disbars him under the laws in Georgia?

context.speaker: Milton Kramer
context.text: I don't know.

context.speaker: Milton Kramer
context.text: I think not.

context.speaker: Milton Kramer
context.text: I don't know.

context.speaker: Milton Kramer
context.text: I can find out.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: Going back to Justice Brennan's --

context.speaker: Milton Kramer
context.text: He furthers his bailiff.

context.speaker: Milton Kramer
context.text: He doesn't do it himself.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: What (Voice Overlap)

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The bailiff (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Milton Kramer
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: Going back to the court's opinion, Justice Brennan asked you this last sentence to be a part of it where the court says “we can only conclude that the sheriff's, the sheriff's intent or his actions constitutes contempt and the conviction on counts 1 and 3 were processed.”

context.speaker: Milton Kramer
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Milton Kramer
context.text: Well, I think that was simply an appellation rather than describing his official capacity.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: And it was a primary for that election.

context.speaker: E. Freeman Leverett
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: And then, he goes on to say that respondent felt and believed that the language which was employed in the charge to the grand jury was of such a nature that it tended to create or emphasize issues likely to have a drastic impact for the outcomes and democratic primary.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: So, wouldn't that put it in exactly the same position as the hypothetical that Justice Black asked you about?

context.speaker: E. Freeman Leverett
context.text: No, sir.

context.speaker: E. Freeman Leverett
context.text: I don't think so.
